All simulations in this work, listed in Tab. 1, are identical in terms of density fields, halo lists and source model. However, they differ in the implementation of the effect of small-scale absorbers. In this section, we describe the five different ways in which we include their effect.

Taking the r40 model, for example, the bubble growth is restricted up to 40 cMpc across all of the EoR. The effect of this is most pronounced when the H ii bubble size reaches the cut-off scale, which in the case for r40 is at redshifts z < 6.3 𝑧 6.3 z<6.3 italic_z < 6.3 (seen as the flattening of the UVB amplitude at Sec.  z < 6.3 𝑧 6.3 z<6.3 italic_z < 6.3 z < 6.3 z z< <6.3 6.3 𝑧 6.3 𝑧 6.3 𝑧 𝑧6.3 6.3z<6.3 z<6.3italic_z < 6.3 italic_z < 6.3 (seen as the flattening of the UVB amplitude at Sec. 4). In comparison, in the LLS40 model, where the barrier is also fixed yet diffuse, the transition scale is smoother since 37 % of the photons (at the Lyman limit) can travel further than the imposed 40 cMpc (see Section 1). Note that, in general, both models produce similar results when compared at a similar global neutral fraction (bottom panel of Fig. 7). Conversely, the C2 model does not display a similar feature and indeed has more power on large scales, when compared in the bottom panel of Fig. 7.

This work aims to explore the role of small-scale optically thick self-shielded systems, which are often not included in large-scale simulations of reionisation. Referred to as Lyman Limit systems, these systems are often associated with hydrogen present in the outskirts of galaxies and/or in the filaments between them (Theuns & Chan, 2024; Fan et al., 2024). LLS have an effect on the observables of reionisation, such as the effective Ly (Theuns & Chan, 2024; Fan et al., 2024). LLS have an effect on the observables of reionisation, such as the effective Ly α 𝛼 \alpha italic_α  opacity, the mean free path of ionising (Lyman continuum) photons, as well as the 21 cm signal from the intergalactic medium. We investigate several methods to model these small-scale absorbers with varying assumptions (see Section  α 𝛼 \alpha italic_α α α 𝛼 𝛼 𝛼\alpha \alphaitalic_α italic_α opacity, the mean free path of ionising (Lyman continuum) photons, as well as the 21 cm signal from the intergalactic medium. We investigate several methods to model these small-scale absorbers with varying assumptions (see Section 2.2 and Table 1).
